SHIP TIMBER.

Love, art thou waking or sleeping p
Shadows with morning should fee -.
Love, art thou smiling or weeping p
Open thy lattice to me -
Sunlight each sorrow heguiling,


Youth should be fearless and free:-
Oh /! when all nature is smiling,


Wilt thou not smile upon me
Think on our last blissful meeting,-
Sunshine dissolving in tears;
Oh! when love's pulses are beating,
Moments are precious as years
Think on the hope that, soft.wiling
Lured me unbidden to thee:
Oh when all nature is smiling,


Wilt thou not smile upon mel
Roses, thy temples once wreathing,
Now on my bosom lie dead -
In their pale beauty still breathing


Fragrance Of hours that have fled
Thus through my heart sweetly thrilling,
Memory whispers to me,
Oh! when all nature is smiling,
Ella will smile upon thee !"

The love Of gaming is the worst Of ills,
With ceaseless storms the blacken'd soul it fills;
Inveghs al Heav'n, peglects the ties of blood,
Destroys the power, and will of doing good
Kills health, pawns honor, plunges in disgrace
And what is still more dreadml-spoils your face.


On the ranked soul
The gaming fury falls; and in gulph
OF total ruin, virtue, peace,
Friends, fani.,es and fortune, headlong sink.


Ihomson's Winter
GAMING.

From the ~ Y Commercial .adrertiser, March g..


THE MORGAN AFFAIR AoAIN.-Thc editors of
he papers a; Buffalo, living near the spot where
he life OF Morgan is supposed to have been tragi-
ally ended, do not yet give full credit to the state
rncnts put forth in the letters which we recently
published. The respectable editor OF the Journal
introduces those letters with the following sceptical
remarks:-


MoRGAN ArrAIR.--We publish the following
letters not because we fully believe the statement
Of facts therein exhibited, but, because We recog
tise in the initials the names Of respectable men !;
and as it is probably from this source that many OF
The rumours now ahoat concerning Morgan. FIRST
took their rise. We cannot bring ourselves to be-
leve the horrible story here res,ed-bnt yet hope,
nay, are bound to believe in the present posture Of
affairs, that the committee have been imposed upon
10 the main particulars. In saying this, however.
we do not in the least doubt the honorable Intentions
Of the gentlemen who wrote the letters, and dis
claim any knowledge which would enable US to
question their statements. We hope knowing as
we do the purity Of principles inculcated BY the
rules Of the order hat the unnatural and unchris


ian conduct detailed below is more the creation Of
the imagination, than history Of facts as they
transpired in christian country-snd are indebted
10 the mystery or the whole transaction, for many
Of its emhellishm enis Should the reality Of this
tale burst upon u.s. or assume shape that shall ad
dress itself full credit, we feel assured that
the community in which we live (as we'll those who
are masoDs as those who are not,) will not be dia
tory in manifssing proper zeal to ferret out the
! "ffenders.


We repeat it, that upon the authority Of vespec-
table names, we hold ourselves in readiness to pub
| lish any evidence upon this subject that may come
10 light. Bot cannot bring ourselves to think
that the inAammatory appeals OF David Z. Miller,
or the proceedings of meetings, aimed al the cha
racter of the whole order, will produce any good
among this or any other community where good
order and morality are held in proper estimaton--
We have, therefore. reGained from publishing them.
Thus far this section Of the country has remained
comparatively quiet. waiting peacesb'y the opera
tion of the laws in the punishment oi the offenders,
so far as they have been identified. We hope It
may long continue so. until something can be found
upon which to base farther proceedings, under the
guidance and power Of the laws.


The Batavia Press, published at the seat OF the
first act Of the drama, holds the following Ian
guage:-


Morgan may be dead--he may have been mar
dered which we strongly suspect 10 be the case ;
but we can hardly believe the facts and circum-
stances would be SO fippsntly told by those who
were concerned in it, this representation would
suppose. 1t would be secret Of too much i'm
pcrtance to the cousprators 10 be talked OF to eve
! ry one, or even to any nne. The manner, too, OF
the murder, is improbable. II it was determined
on, what need OF trial9 Men engaged in so
dark aud horr'd transaction murder. not apt
TO use muck circumlocution, or roundabout cere-
mony; ueilhcr are our citizens, if led by passion,
or interest, to commit murder, ap, to display unne-
csssary and savage cruelty. They would hardly
be so foolish as TO cut mans threat, and leave
traces of blood fer the pleasure of torturing
their victim whom they ultimately intended to secret
in the lake. when the lake iself would do the deed
Of dea,h, as we'll ae the knife"
From the ". Y Commercial .9drertiser, March 6

CONDITIONS OF THE WATCHMAN.

withhold, or bestow upon other presses, which have
given the whole information" Another resolution,
denounces the Governor for having, as they falsely
say, issued two procIamations Of doubtful charac-
ter, when of the right kind would have answer,
ed a much better purpose Another resolution
ridculously enough resolves that they will adherc
to the last feeling advice of the father OF our couD~
try, and particularly the caution to beware OF all
secret societies believing that it must have been tho
mysteries and secrets Of masonry to which he au-
ded in his Farewell Add,ess'' When in fact
Washington was a Mason, and Grand Master of tho
order! Another resolution censures the Sheriff.
Tor treating those who are in confinement, undergo
ing the sentence of the Court with too much hui
maniy ssc.-as though they were TO be left to
freeze and starve in their cells These resolutions
are not only ridiculous, but cold uneeng, and un-
just Should robbery. murder be committed
in Ohio public meeting might with the same pro-
prety resolve that the people of Ohio were all rob-
bers and murderers, as this Canandsgua meeting
resolve that they will never support Freemason
Tor any Office. Or should horse be stolen in
Ontario county, the whole population might by the
same rule be pronounced horse, thieves.
Another popular meeting was held at Ulysses
Tompkins county. on The lath oi February at whcia
fourteen resolutions of a character very similar to-
those described above-full of zeal without knowl
edge or discretion adopted. In some
spects however, this meeting went farther thar ,has
at Canandaigua They libel the order, by detlar-
ing that the great majority of masons couDenanced
the outrage. They moreover resolve to use all law
full efforts to accomplish the downfall Of the instu
tion-censure the Court, denounce some OF Inc
newspapers, praise others, &c. Now it strikes Us,
that such intemperate proceedings will have q
tendency to do vastly more harm than good And
it persisted in, they will most certainly produce
| action.


the 5,h of February, of which Jacob Falznger was
chairman, and c. L Haskins secretary The re-
solutions adopted at this meeting, were more tempe
rate than those of the other meetings.
| The same paper which contains the proceedings
Of this meeting, (,he Ithaca Chronicle.) contains also
the proceedings Of Charity Lodge, in-Danby, at
meeting held on the 10Th. From these proceedings
we extract the following honorable, temperate, and
judcious resolves: "a


"Whereas it is publicly asserted that the persons who
were concerned in tha, transaction Freemasons.
And whereas Freemasons, body, have been cha ged
with conniving at these unlawful proceedings.
Resotyed, Therefore, that discam any knowledge
Of participation in The transaction either
ctzens and that this Lodge dsapproyes Of the proceed


ngs of those persons who concerned in that transact


ton, whoever they may have been and that we consider


be an outrage on personal liberty, and hasrant vio
Istion of the laws of the land.


Resolved act we will Cooperate with our fellow cii4
in all lawful eorsto bring the facts pertaining to ths
mysterious affair to light.


Resolved That consider the resolutions that have
been passed certain public meetings in this and othe~
countless charging the masonic institution with ccnnivrg
person
manifesng spirit and temper unbecomng the enlighten
ed age in which we live"


Several Of the western lodges and chapters have
taken similar course, and believe that most if
not all, Of those who have been directly i'm
pIicaed in carrying Morgan off have been expelled
from their respective lodges. This as it should
be. To quote the appropriate language OF ives"
tern paper


g These violations, which would disgrace savage
people Uere not committed by masons. That they
were committed by men who profess to be masons---
| by men Who belong to the masonic institution, we
do not deny but we do deny that these men
any more masons, than hypocrites, in consequence
OF their belonging 10 church, are christians. We
say let the genuine masons set their faces flint
against such conduct, well as against those who
countenance connive at so foul deed And we
say let imprisonment be the fate of all those who
are guilty, until Morgan is restored or satisfactorily
accounted for.''


| We come now to another article, which raises
another doubt, and involves another important con-
tradciion: The Peoples Press, published al Baa-
via, of Saturday last, says" We authorized Iy
one of the Delegates to the LeUston Conrention to
state that no signs Of BLOOD, or any other proba
BILE evidences Of the murder Of Morgan, any body
else, were discovered at or about TT. Niagara"
Here, then one OF the stronees, circumstances IA
voripg the conclusion that Morgan was murdered
at Fort Niagara, is positively denied by one OF the
Lew iston Convention, which was SAID to have made
the appalling discovery Ought not editors there
fore to pause before they attempt to add oil to
fame which is already raging With sufficient vio-
Iencep


In concluding this article, already far longer than
we could have desired, VIC come TO point more
imme edatey interesting to ourselves. About ten
days ago We informed that one of the indisi
duals implicated as principal in this sad affair."
had passed through this city on his wsy to Wash
inpton, where our informant said he then was. This

In one Of the letters which we have alluded to
above, our readers may recollect the following
passage:-


"His informer i. e. the Doctor who was the in
former oil Mr.. Cook, one Of the investigating COM
mittee, was Of that place, a
brother of -. Of Buffalo. The Doctor
does not think him implicated. but thinks he had
his information from M .... His statement
was all put in writing in the form Of an affidavit,
which he stands ready to sign al any time it shall
be needed. He also informed Us, that he had a
short time afterwards relation OF the same facts
from smother mason Of the name of L who
had it from Mr.. c of Buffalo, who was
an actor in the scene Of the night of the 14th-he
is since dead"


! The person here alluded to as Mr.. c. Of Bufa
TO-" was Mr.. Seth Chaplin, of that village, since
dead. The editor of the Buffalo Journal however,
states, positively, that the memory Of this man " is
most grossly slandered, by this imputation. He
was not, as will be Proved If necessary out OF this
village at the time mentioned, nor could he be, ow
ing to sickness in his family He is dead, and we
envy not the man whose heated Imagination has so
far clouded his reason to drive him among the
tombs, to search for proofs Of what never was.-
Neither cur liberties morals will be render
ed more safe by yielding the direction of judicial
tribunals to the hands of men who 80 far forget
right, as to invade, in a moment of phrenzy, the





idle rumor, regardless Of the feelings OF friends, or
the reputation of children still in their infancy"
The following note, also, from Col. Chaplin, the
brother Of the deceased, is likewise published in
the Journal.


TO THE PUBLIC.


The feelings Of myself and family been cruelty out
ragged by communication recently published in the Ma


onal Observer and repubshed by number of other pa
pers duplicating departed friend Mr. Seth Chaplin,
being concerned in the alleged murder Of William Morgan
fn f1rntty tn
the memory of departed friend to to the
public, that the publication referred far it respects
the late Seth Chaplin having any knowledge in
the affair of William Morgan, an entire fabrication, and
wholly destitute of the least sembance Of TRUTH and could
originated in other feelings than those of the ba
ses and most malignant kind AT the time Of the alleged
ing his domestic concerns, and for number ct days both
preceding and following that tme confined home by
the sickness of his family and not during that time ab
all from the village of Buffalo Incontestble proof
Of these facts will shortly be laid before the public; and
have only TO observe, further. that proper win
Immediately be taken ferret the author of this
wicked and malignant SANDER and those SHALL
trust they may be, successful in unmasking the vile
umnisor, he shall not escape that punsnmen, which his
wickedness and unprovoked magn,y have SO Justly mer
ted. CYRENlUS CHAPLIN.


Buffalo, Feb. 10, 1927.


Here, then, We have another case of cruel inius
tice which has been caused by the present excite
ment in regard to this unhappy business. We say
- another CASE" because 1t is now certain that
innocent man has been convicted, and is now in
prison for crime in which he had not the least
participa,ion--nay, was not in the county when il
was committed. And now it appears that another,
who was represented by the investigating commit.
mttee having been an actor in The bloody deed,
was at home, with sick family, eighteen or TWEEN
ty miles distant 1t is time for discreet men TO
pause, therefore, lest others may be cruelty wrong
ed likewise.


In one Of those letters moreover, it was repre-.
IF he cfA
Telegraph. who was appointed one Of the Delegates
10 the Lewiston Convention, did not go in conse-
uuence OF having been threatened by the mssons.
This, Mr.. Weed fully and explicitly denes-so
that one cause of reproach is taken from the mason
ic character.


| The Editor Of the Rochester Telegraph complains
of the late proceedings Of the Grand Chapter upon
this subject and says the language of their resolu-
tons, sc. is cold and cquvocal. He also says that
there were men sitting in that body, whose hands
were reeking with Morgan's blood. Now we have
one simple question TO ask II those gentlemen at
the West know with so much certainty, who were
engaged in the affair, and they tell US they know,
ard publish their nitials-why do they not procure
their arrest? Where are the Grand Juries? What
has become OF the officers and Ministers Of Justice
at the Westa We must confess that the mystery
increases, and those who have undertaken 10 bring
the truth to tight. have yet only increased the
darkness.


| The foregoing article was prepared thus fer two
or three days ago, but has been unavoidably delay
cd Meantime, the western papers have furnished
US sundry additional articles respeetng Morgan, to-
gether with the proceedings of three more Nor
gan meetings." as they termed. One of these
meetings was held at Canandaeua on the 10th ult.
Of which Henry Gushing Chairman and Oliver
Hearwell Secretary. No less than thirteen reso.
lutioEs were passed, some of which, we regret to
say, indicate spirit scarcely less ferocous than
manifested by those who took Morgan of. One is,
| thai thew @ view rnasnnrp as a danpernus fenden.
WILMINGTON, Del. TUESDAY, MARCH 1s, 1927

full articles.headline: a SERENADE.
full articles.article:
Love, art thou waking or sleeping p
Shadows with morning should fee -.
Love, art thou smiling or weeping p
Open thy lattice to me -
Sunlight each sorrow heguiling,


Youth should be fearless and free:-
Oh /! when all nature is smiling,


Wilt thou not smile upon me
Think on our last blissful meeting,-
Sunshine dissolving in tears;
Oh! when love's pulses are beating,
Moments are precious as years
Think on the hope that, soft.wiling
Lured me unbidden to thee:
Oh when all nature is smiling,


Wilt thou not smile upon mel
Roses, thy temples once wreathing,
Now on my bosom lie dead -
In their pale beauty still breathing


Fragrance Of hours that have fled
Thus through my heart sweetly thrilling,
Memory whispers to me,
Oh! when all nature is smiling,
Ella will smile upon thee !"

awood yard for number of years. There are two frame
buildings thereon the occupied stable, and the
other store room.


No. 3-Five acres of marsh, situate in the said Borough
in Clemens Creek marsl adjoining marsh Of Joseph Bay
and Others which may be divided into three lots TO suit
purchasers


The sale TO commence at two O'clock when attendance
will be given and conditions made known by


JOSEPH POCUE, Swv,,ng Erecutoy.
Wilmington, Feb Esd. 1897. 32-5t

full articles.headline: GAMING.
full articles.article:
The love Of gaming is the worst Of ills,
With ceaseless storms the blacken'd soul it fills;
Inveghs al Heav'n, peglects the ties of blood,
Destroys the power, and will of doing good
Kills health, pawns honor, plunges in disgrace
And what is still more dreadml-spoils your face.


On the ranked soul
The gaming fury falls; and in gulph
OF total ruin, virtue, peace,
Friends, fani.,es and fortune, headlong sink.


Ihomson's Winter

full articles.headline: From the ". Y Commercial .9drertiser, March 6
full articles.article:
From the ~ Y Commercial .adrertiser, March g..


THE MORGAN AFFAIR AoAIN.-Thc editors of
he papers a; Buffalo, living near the spot where
he life OF Morgan is supposed to have been tragi-
ally ended, do not yet give full credit to the state
rncnts put forth in the letters which we recently
published. The respectable editor OF the Journal
introduces those letters with the following sceptical
remarks:-


MoRGAN ArrAIR.--We publish the following
letters not because we fully believe the statement
Of facts therein exhibited, but, because We recog
tise in the initials the names Of respectable men !;
and as it is probably from this source that many OF
The rumours now ahoat concerning Morgan. FIRST
took their rise. We cannot bring ourselves to be-
leve the horrible story here res,ed-bnt yet hope,
nay, are bound to believe in the present posture Of
affairs, that the committee have been imposed upon
10 the main particulars. In saying this, however.
we do not in the least doubt the honorable Intentions
Of the gentlemen who wrote the letters, and dis
claim any knowledge which would enable US to
question their statements. We hope knowing as
we do the purity Of principles inculcated BY the
rules Of the order hat the unnatural and unchris


ian conduct detailed below is more the creation Of
the imagination, than history Of facts as they
transpired in christian country-snd are indebted
10 the mystery or the whole transaction, for many
Of its emhellishm enis Should the reality Of this
tale burst upon u.s. or assume shape that shall ad
dress itself full credit, we feel assured that
the community in which we live (as we'll those who
are masoDs as those who are not,) will not be dia
tory in manifssing proper zeal to ferret out the
! "ffenders.


We repeat it, that upon the authority Of vespec-
table names, we hold ourselves in readiness to pub
| lish any evidence upon this subject that may come
10 light. Bot cannot bring ourselves to think
that the inAammatory appeals OF David Z. Miller,
or the proceedings of meetings, aimed al the cha
racter of the whole order, will produce any good
among this or any other community where good
order and morality are held in proper estimaton--
We have, therefore. reGained from publishing them.
Thus far this section Of the country has remained
comparatively quiet. waiting peacesb'y the opera
tion of the laws in the punishment oi the offenders,
so far as they have been identified. We hope It
may long continue so. until something can be found
upon which to base farther proceedings, under the
guidance and power Of the laws.


The Batavia Press, published at the seat OF the
first act Of the drama, holds the following Ian
guage:-


Morgan may be dead--he may have been mar
dered which we strongly suspect 10 be the case ;
but we can hardly believe the facts and circum-
stances would be SO fippsntly told by those who
were concerned in it, this representation would
suppose. 1t would be secret Of too much i'm
pcrtance to the cousprators 10 be talked OF to eve
! ry one, or even to any nne. The manner, too, OF
the murder, is improbable. II it was determined
on, what need OF trial9 Men engaged in so
dark aud horr'd transaction murder. not apt
TO use muck circumlocution, or roundabout cere-
mony; ueilhcr are our citizens, if led by passion,
or interest, to commit murder, ap, to display unne-
csssary and savage cruelty. They would hardly
be so foolish as TO cut mans threat, and leave
traces of blood fer the pleasure of torturing
their victim whom they ultimately intended to secret
in the lake. when the lake iself would do the deed
Of dea,h, as we'll ae the knife"

borion Advertisers requested specify in writing

ddDertssing bytheyear.
BIO Subscribers. To Mons Subscribers
year SIS, O0 i year S18 90
months 8, 90 months 9, so
do. A, SO 3 do. 500

withhold, or bestow upon other presses, which have
given the whole information" Another resolution,
denounces the Governor for having, as they falsely
say, issued two procIamations Of doubtful charac-
ter, when of the right kind would have answer,
ed a much better purpose Another resolution
ridculously enough resolves that they will adherc
to the last feeling advice of the father OF our couD~
try, and particularly the caution to beware OF all
secret societies believing that it must have been tho
mysteries and secrets Of masonry to which he au-
ded in his Farewell Add,ess'' When in fact
Washington was a Mason, and Grand Master of tho
order! Another resolution censures the Sheriff.
Tor treating those who are in confinement, undergo
ing the sentence of the Court with too much hui
maniy ssc.-as though they were TO be left to
freeze and starve in their cells These resolutions
are not only ridiculous, but cold uneeng, and un-
just Should robbery. murder be committed
in Ohio public meeting might with the same pro-
prety resolve that the people of Ohio were all rob-
bers and murderers, as this Canandsgua meeting
resolve that they will never support Freemason
Tor any Office. Or should horse be stolen in
Ontario county, the whole population might by the
same rule be pronounced horse, thieves.
Another popular meeting was held at Ulysses
Tompkins county. on The lath oi February at whcia
fourteen resolutions of a character very similar to-
those described above-full of zeal without knowl
edge or discretion adopted. In some
spects however, this meeting went farther thar ,has
at Canandaigua They libel the order, by detlar-
ing that the great majority of masons couDenanced
the outrage. They moreover resolve to use all law
full efforts to accomplish the downfall Of the instu
tion-censure the Court, denounce some OF Inc
newspapers, praise others, &c. Now it strikes Us,
that such intemperate proceedings will have q
tendency to do vastly more harm than good And
it persisted in, they will most certainly produce
| action.


the 5,h of February, of which Jacob Falznger was
chairman, and c. L Haskins secretary The re-
solutions adopted at this meeting, were more tempe
rate than those of the other meetings.
| The same paper which contains the proceedings
Of this meeting, (,he Ithaca Chronicle.) contains also
the proceedings Of Charity Lodge, in-Danby, at
meeting held on the 10Th. From these proceedings
we extract the following honorable, temperate, and
judcious resolves: "a


"Whereas it is publicly asserted that the persons who
were concerned in tha, transaction Freemasons.
And whereas Freemasons, body, have been cha ged
with conniving at these unlawful proceedings.
Resotyed, Therefore, that discam any knowledge
Of participation in The transaction either
ctzens and that this Lodge dsapproyes Of the proceed


ngs of those persons who concerned in that transact


ton, whoever they may have been and that we consider


be an outrage on personal liberty, and hasrant vio
Istion of the laws of the land.


Resolved act we will Cooperate with our fellow cii4
in all lawful eorsto bring the facts pertaining to ths
mysterious affair to light.


Resolved That consider the resolutions that have
been passed certain public meetings in this and othe~
countless charging the masonic institution with ccnnivrg
person
manifesng spirit and temper unbecomng the enlighten
ed age in which we live"


Several Of the western lodges and chapters have
taken similar course, and believe that most if
not all, Of those who have been directly i'm
pIicaed in carrying Morgan off have been expelled
from their respective lodges. This as it should
be. To quote the appropriate language OF ives"
tern paper


g These violations, which would disgrace savage
people Uere not committed by masons. That they
were committed by men who profess to be masons---
| by men Who belong to the masonic institution, we
do not deny but we do deny that these men
any more masons, than hypocrites, in consequence
OF their belonging 10 church, are christians. We
say let the genuine masons set their faces flint
against such conduct, well as against those who
countenance connive at so foul deed And we
say let imprisonment be the fate of all those who
are guilty, until Morgan is restored or satisfactorily
accounted for.''


| We come now to another article, which raises
another doubt, and involves another important con-
tradciion: The Peoples Press, published al Baa-
via, of Saturday last, says" We authorized Iy
one of the Delegates to the LeUston Conrention to
state that no signs Of BLOOD, or any other proba
BILE evidences Of the murder Of Morgan, any body
else, were discovered at or about TT. Niagara"
Here, then one OF the stronees, circumstances IA
voripg the conclusion that Morgan was murdered
at Fort Niagara, is positively denied by one OF the
Lew iston Convention, which was SAID to have made
the appalling discovery Ought not editors there
fore to pause before they attempt to add oil to
fame which is already raging With sufficient vio-
Iencep


In concluding this article, already far longer than
we could have desired, VIC come TO point more
imme edatey interesting to ourselves. About ten
days ago We informed that one of the indisi
duals implicated as principal in this sad affair."
had passed through this city on his wsy to Wash
inpton, where our informant said he then was. This

full articles.headline: WILMINGTON, Del. TUESDAY, MARCH 1s, 1927
full articles.article:
In one Of the letters which we have alluded to
above, our readers may recollect the following
passage:-


"His informer i. e. the Doctor who was the in
former oil Mr.. Cook, one Of the investigating COM
mittee, was Of that place, a
brother of -. Of Buffalo. The Doctor
does not think him implicated. but thinks he had
his information from M .... His statement
was all put in writing in the form Of an affidavit,
which he stands ready to sign al any time it shall
be needed. He also informed Us, that he had a
short time afterwards relation OF the same facts
from smother mason Of the name of L who
had it from Mr.. c of Buffalo, who was
an actor in the scene Of the night of the 14th-he
is since dead"


! The person here alluded to as Mr.. c. Of Bufa
TO-" was Mr.. Seth Chaplin, of that village, since
dead. The editor of the Buffalo Journal however,
states, positively, that the memory Of this man " is
most grossly slandered, by this imputation. He
was not, as will be Proved If necessary out OF this
village at the time mentioned, nor could he be, ow
ing to sickness in his family He is dead, and we
envy not the man whose heated Imagination has so
far clouded his reason to drive him among the
tombs, to search for proofs Of what never was.-
Neither cur liberties morals will be render
ed more safe by yielding the direction of judicial
tribunals to the hands of men who 80 far forget
right, as to invade, in a moment of phrenzy, the





idle rumor, regardless Of the feelings OF friends, or
the reputation of children still in their infancy"
The following note, also, from Col. Chaplin, the
brother Of the deceased, is likewise published in
the Journal.


TO THE PUBLIC.


The feelings Of myself and family been cruelty out
ragged by communication recently published in the Ma


onal Observer and repubshed by number of other pa
pers duplicating departed friend Mr. Seth Chaplin,
being concerned in the alleged murder Of William Morgan
fn f1rntty tn
the memory of departed friend to to the
public, that the publication referred far it respects
the late Seth Chaplin having any knowledge in
the affair of William Morgan, an entire fabrication, and
wholly destitute of the least sembance Of TRUTH and could
originated in other feelings than those of the ba
ses and most malignant kind AT the time Of the alleged
ing his domestic concerns, and for number ct days both
preceding and following that tme confined home by
the sickness of his family and not during that time ab
all from the village of Buffalo Incontestble proof
Of these facts will shortly be laid before the public; and
have only TO observe, further. that proper win
Immediately be taken ferret the author of this
wicked and malignant SANDER and those SHALL
trust they may be, successful in unmasking the vile
umnisor, he shall not escape that punsnmen, which his
wickedness and unprovoked magn,y have SO Justly mer
ted. CYRENlUS CHAPLIN.


Buffalo, Feb. 10, 1927.


Here, then, We have another case of cruel inius
tice which has been caused by the present excite
ment in regard to this unhappy business. We say
- another CASE" because 1t is now certain that
innocent man has been convicted, and is now in
prison for crime in which he had not the least
participa,ion--nay, was not in the county when il
was committed. And now it appears that another,
who was represented by the investigating commit.
mttee having been an actor in The bloody deed,
was at home, with sick family, eighteen or TWEEN
ty miles distant 1t is time for discreet men TO
pause, therefore, lest others may be cruelty wrong
ed likewise.


In one Of those letters moreover, it was repre-.
IF he cfA
Telegraph. who was appointed one Of the Delegates
10 the Lewiston Convention, did not go in conse-
uuence OF having been threatened by the mssons.
This, Mr.. Weed fully and explicitly denes-so
that one cause of reproach is taken from the mason
ic character.


| The Editor Of the Rochester Telegraph complains
of the late proceedings Of the Grand Chapter upon
this subject and says the language of their resolu-
tons, sc. is cold and cquvocal. He also says that
there were men sitting in that body, whose hands
were reeking with Morgan's blood. Now we have
one simple question TO ask II those gentlemen at
the West know with so much certainty, who were
engaged in the affair, and they tell US they know,
ard publish their nitials-why do they not procure
their arrest? Where are the Grand Juries? What
has become OF the officers and Ministers Of Justice
at the Westa We must confess that the mystery
increases, and those who have undertaken 10 bring
the truth to tight. have yet only increased the
darkness.


| The foregoing article was prepared thus fer two
or three days ago, but has been unavoidably delay
cd Meantime, the western papers have furnished
US sundry additional articles respeetng Morgan, to-
gether with the proceedings of three more Nor
gan meetings." as they termed. One of these
meetings was held at Canandaeua on the 10th ult.
Of which Henry Gushing Chairman and Oliver
Hearwell Secretary. No less than thirteen reso.
lutioEs were passed, some of which, we regret to
say, indicate spirit scarcely less ferocous than
manifested by those who took Morgan of. One is,
| thai thew @ view rnasnnrp as a danpernus fenden.
